I too was stuck on losing extra weight, but I was able to break through that set point by increasing aerobic activity prior to lifting at the athletic club. It took a few extra weeks before my weight began to drop again.

At 53 my knees are a pretty regular pain, (nobody told me to become a ski bum at 40 so it's my own fault) and the shoulders hurt too. What I've found to be a push up "light" is to stand in a doorway, hands on the frame, feet back around 24" and push away. The intensity can be modified by moving feet closer or farther to the doorway thereby adjusting the body angle. I love hiking but find biking a lot easier on the knees, tons of fun and a great aerobic.

I try to do everything on my toes. It seems natural to me. I cannot figure out how using your heels takes weight off your knees.

@ETIsHome

It's not exactly that "weight" is taken off your knees. Imagine for a moment a person at the bottom of a deep squat, with their feet flat. Now imagine them moving up onto their toes; what happens to their knee and hip angle?

You may have to do this yourself to see it. What will happen is that the knee angle will shorten, and then the hip angle will open. This roughly corresponds to increased use of the quads, and decreased use of the ham strings and glutes, and more stretch on the connective tissues of the knee. The fact that the hamstrings are shortened in this position can also lead to a net anterior shear on the knee, as the quad pulls the tibia forward. If the feet are flat, forces are more evenly distributed between the knee and hip joint.

So, since we (presumably) want to train our ham strings and glutes, and do not want to injure our knees, having one's heals on the ground is probably a good idea. Also, add the fact that you are just more stable with feet flat on the ground, and you probably want to be stable when you have a big heavy thing on your shoulders.

Now, there are lots of other activities where you do want to be on your toes. And if we are talking about unweighted squats, it is probably fine to be on your toes since the forces involved are not so high. But if you are going to attempt a heavy barbell squat, heels on the ground is a good idea.

Some (all due disclaimers in effect) advice from an old and feisty lifelong weightlifter. Take it for what it's worth, which is a very great deal. ;)

********
It's good that people are discovering the superb virtues of basic barbell moves like the squat and deadlift, but this has led to an epidemic of bad form. If there is any single thing I would advise the beginning lifter, or the strong young buck who thinks he's anything else, it's this:

When you squat or deadlift, remember that *both* of these movements target the massive musculature of the lower body, esp. your hamstrings and your glutes. Knowing this, make sure as you do these movements to keep your spine straight with a slight arch at the base of the back; and always *think of your heels* as you squat or deadlift.

Thinking of your heels when you squat will help prevent you from coming forward and putting immense pressure on your knees; the same thing is true when you pull a deadlift -- you should always be thinking about driving your heels into the ground.

Never rush these exercises; never "explode" up. Just move at a comfortable place, allowing your hamstrings, glutes and quads to engage and lift the weight. Remember: you do not pull a deadlift up with your arms -- your arms are simply attached to the barbell.

When I say "think of your heels," I mean exactly that: think about your heels as you squat and deadlift. That trains your brain and locks in your form.

See next post for more advice.

Cont.

Learn how to do a correct hyperextension. This is a *severely underrated* exercise which can have *seemingly miraculous* positive effects for those with chronic lower-back pain and lumbar disc issues.

Start slowly and learn the correct form: do not place your hands behind your neck; do not cross your arms in from of your chest. Simply allow your arms to hang down freely. Slowly, thinking at all times about the muscles in your lower-back, raise yourself to a comfortable height; then allow your body to go all the way down, essentially folding in half. Slowly raise again. As you grow stronger you will find yourself extending your range of motion quite a bit; once this occurs, consider adding weight. You will hold this weight with your arms extended and your elbows locked. Remember: the muscles of your lower-back are lifting the weight, whether it's the weight of your body or your body plus additional weight. Always think of the lower-back as you do these. It's an enormously useful exercise, and inexplicably neglected.

Finally. Learn how to do a full pullup. If you can't do one, do machine-assisted pullups until you're able to execute one perfect, high pullup. Ideally use a straight-bar, with your palms facing away from you, a little more than shoulder width. Do not yank yourself up; think about your the large muscles of your back, your lats, and pull up at an even pace, as high as you can. Lower yourself to a fully extended resting position.

Enjoy.
And the Sunday Times is heavy enough that you get the benefit of weightlifting.

VERY SIMPLE ADVISE

I get up and the first thing I do is pick up my copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES. I go to the obits and if I don't see my name, I make a cup of coffee and sample the many interesting articles in THE TIMES.

My avoiding any weight training gives me more time to read THE TIMES.

Nearly everything I read about physical fitness neglects one imortant point: we are all a little different and should listen to our bodies as much as we listen to experts.

It seems obvious that both cardio and strength training should be parts of a regular regimine. The most important thing is to get off your duff and do SOMETHING! Some are orthodox about specific routines while others, myself included, find favorites but make a point of mixing it up to get the body prepared for whatever may come.

Strength training, frequently weights, is key to keeping all the parts and pieces, (muscles, tendons, ligaments) happy and healthy. Cardio exercises, (running, biking, treadmill, aerobic dance etc) seem to be as good for the head as for the heart and are just darn good fun to boot. I couldn't imagine going without either.

Go heavy with few reps, go lighter with more reps, do body weight  movements such as pushups, pullups, air squats, jump onto boxes, jump rope, run, swim, bikle, use dumbbells and kettlebells, do complex movements such as back squats, deadlifts and barbell thrusters, find a Crossfit or similar gym with a good coach, keep your workouts safe and varied to avoid boredom, and have fun!

Until fatigue of the primary muscle group you are exercising. Until you can't finish the lift without giving yourself a hernia!

Also most of the stuff I have read (which they maybe should have mentioned) is the importance of resting the exercised muscles. Switching between fatiguing a muscle group, then resting it the next day or two so your body reacts to the exercise and builds more muscle there.

"For many of us, weight training is a mysterious and intimidating activity. People often ask me if they really need to lift weights..." Hard to believe but, If that's the case, you should suggest they explore TRX Suspension Training.

I think its time to throw out whether a decision fits in with X years of "jurisprudence". What the court is supposed to be doing is to determine whether a law fits the Constitution, not whether it fits the opinion of passed on Supreme Court justices. Sticking to the Constitution is NOT judicial activism, that is their duty.
The Winning Progressive's last paragraph sums it up beautifully.

WP is very silly.  Over the last 200 years the Supreme Court has periodically become nescient and excessively literal about either the language of the Constitution of 1789 or what the S.Ct. seems to take as the divinely inspired musings of John Marshall.  Eventually there is always a reaction.  In the 1850s Roger Taney attempted to blend the “fugitive slave” clause of Article IV with Marshall’s musings on the “supremacy” clause and gave us Scott v. Sanford and civil war.  Later the “New Deal” court attempted to blend the “commerce clause” with Marshall’s musings in “Gibbons v. Ogden” and gave us Wickard v. Filburn.

So you're a fan of judicial restraint, Mr. Douthat?

Does that mean you object to the ruling in Bush v. Gore, which carried the ultimate imprimatur of judicial activism - namely, the unprecedented inclusion of a statement that the decision had no precedential value.

Does that mean you object to Citizens United and the follow-up decision not to hear an appeal from the court decision overturning Montana's campaign finance laws? Because both decisions overruled validly passed campaign finance laws that were designed to protect our democracy from turning into an open system of bribery.

Does that mean you will object if the Court overturns health care reform? As two leading conservative judges, Jeffrey Sutton and Laurence Silberman, both found in upholding health care reform, the shared responsibility ("individual mandate") provision that is the focus of attacks on health care reform easily fits within nearly 80 years of Commerce Clause jurisprudence, that today's Court would have to wipe out to invalidate the legislatively enacted health care reform.

The simple reality is that both sides engage in judicial activism. The difference is that progressive justices do so to protect our civil liberties and equality, while conservatives do so in order to further the interests of corporate interests and conservative politicians.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
